narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: An understanding of educational history and the challenges of reform.

got a better understand of why schools won't save us, the perils of law school and graduate education, the myth of American meritocracy, and other interesting topics related to how people have approached teaching education over time
history of and perspectives on our current system of education (in the US, but also in Europe/the West generally), Skills for analytical reading, making and defending an argument drawing on readings.
I learned a lot about the history of education and the many factors that impact our experiences in higher education today.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: No weaknesses. Strengths are Prof. Levy-Eichel, whose praises I cannot sing highly enough.

the professor was pretty chill and the class is not a super stressful environment; for the semester-long project, I wish there were more check-ins, just for accountability reasons, but this is also just a personal preference and doesn't;t reflect poorly on the course whatsoever

Strength: Small size of group, felt as close to an actual in person discussion as possible. Made it possible to "get-to-know" other students and learn their backgrounds, personal interests and histories, points of view.
Strength: Professor, who knew many of the students from other classes/engagements, often encouraged students to bring their work and backgrounds from outside of class into class. This made discussions more honest and interesting.
Weakness: This class would have been much more fun in person, but alas, the times. 
Strength: Cold calling to get the conversation started worked well, held us accountable to reading but then Professor found good balance of letting discussion flow organically 
Strength: diversity of readings and formats

Strengths: discussion format, was especially nice that we talked about the readings from a broader perspective and made connections, rather than just summarizing the readings. Weaknesses: sometimes I felt like we went off on tangents, and I would have appreciated more background to the readings for some weeks (i.e. for the first week, Mordechai talked a little bit about the history, which framed the readings better).

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: yes. you should take it just for the subject matter and the opportunity to reflect on your own interpretations of education and its value/utility

Yes! For sure -- do the readings, expect the professor to challenge you and ask you to back up your claims. Be prepared for your identity as a college student at Yale to be challenged. Bring your own personal experiences into the classroom!

Yes! Mordechai is a fantastic professor, and is so willing to incorporate students' feedback (i.e. 5 minute break during our 2 hour Zoom seminar). Also, the discussion format really allows for you to get the most out of the readings, and I loved listening to my classmates' opinions. Reading amount varies by week, but is reasonable, and especially if you get a head start on it and actually do the readings, you'll be in a good place for the oral final.
